docs.snippet: Eight commanders and generals sat in a circle in a rocky ravine, as hundreds of their fighters watched from nearby crags and hillsides. The peaceful scene ended the latest bout of fighting here in northern Afghanistan, a five-day clash between the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Eight commanders and generals sat in a circle in a rocky ravine, as hundreds of their fighters watched from nearby crags and hillsides. The peaceful scene ended the latest bout of fighting here in northern Afghanistan, a five-day clash between the Northern Alliance and a local leader trying to regain power. It ended with negotiation and without bloodshed, as directed by top officials of the alliance's Defense Ministry. By satellite telephone, they stressed the need to avoid any more fighting.
docs.abstract: Clash between Afghanistan's Northern Alliance and Sayed Jaffar, local leader of Ismaili people, ends peacefully; his representative meets with alliance and says he erred in marching with hundreds of troops on Pul-i-Khumri in bid to regain power; he offers to surrender, then flees with all his soldiers and residents of Kayan, his home village; his deserted headquarters show clear signs of recent United States special forces presences; Alliance has charged US backed Jaffar and called airstrikes against its forces when they opposed his move on city; holds Jaffar tricked Americans into thinking they were attacking Taliban; photo (M)

headline.main: Clash With Afghan Group Ends With Talks, Bloodlessly

docs.snippet: The political divide here deepened today as the Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, defended the arrests of an American diplomat and a senior Serbian government official for espionage -- arrests that other leaders condemned as politically cont...
docs.lead_paragraph: The political divide here deepened today as the Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, defended the arrests of an American diplomat and a senior Serbian government official for espionage -- arrests that other leaders condemned as politically contrived. ''From what I have managed to find out up until now, the legality of the procedure itself should not be disputed,'' Mr. Kostunica said early this morning after hours of meetings with government and army officials.
docs.abstract: Yugoslav Pres Vojislav Kostunica defends arrests of American diplomat John David Neighbor and senior Serbian government official Momcilo Perisic for espionage; local news media report men are suspected of leaking documents that could help convict former leader Slobodan Milosevic in his trial for war crimes at The Hague; Kostunica's statement will likely deepen his rift with Prime Min Zoran Djindjic, who has called arrests 'scandal'; Perisic has been released and Neighbor, who has diplomatic immunity, was released earlier; officials at American Embassy are outraged at arrest of Neighbor (M)

headline.main: Yugoslav Chief Defends Arrest Of American For Espionage

docs.snippet: Michael Finkel's article (Dec. 16) put a very human face on the war in Afghanistan. This short article did more to say what the war is about and to bring home the fact that nothing is ever simple in this messy business of human existence than all ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Michael Finkel's article (Dec. 16) put a very human face on the war in Afghanistan. This short article did more to say what the war is about and to bring home the fact that nothing is ever simple in this messy business of human existence than all the ''pundits'' I have read in the past weeks. Arlene Distler Brattleboro, Vt.
docs.abstract: Arlene Distler letter hails Michael Finkel's Dec 16 article for putting human face on war in Afghanistan

docs.snippet: The countries of sub-Saharan Africa have always had to fight for America's attention. Lately, most have fallen off the map.    Nowhere is that clearer than in Congo, which has been ravaged by a three-year civil war with five foreign armies taking ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The countries of sub-Saharan Africa have always had to fight for America's attention. Lately, most have fallen off the map. Nowhere is that clearer than in Congo, which has been ravaged by a three-year civil war with five foreign armies taking part. Earlier this year, President Joseph Kabila, whose father and predecessor, Laurent D. Kabila, had been assassinated in January, promised to revive flagging peace accords and won praise from Washington. But recently there have been setbacks, little noticed in the United States. Peace talks to lay the groundwork for a transitional government collapsed in October. In November, the United Nations reported that countries like Uganda, Rwanda and Zimbabwe were continuing to plunder Congo's riches, while relief agencies say soldiers engage in widespread looting and extortion.
docs.abstract: Countries of sub-Saharan Africa have fallen off map in United States in wake of Sept 11; Congo has been ravaged by three-year civil war, in Eritrea, there has been crackdown on government critics, in Burundi, long-running civil war continues, and in Zimbabwe, anyone challenging Pres Robert Mugabe is rounded up and charged with being terrorist; AIDS continues its relentless creep across continent (M)

headline.main: Imagine; The Struggle to be Heard

docs.snippet: The Bush administration is concerned that the approach of warmer weather in Afghanistan may signal a sharp rise in guerrilla attacks on American and allied troops, senior officials say.    Significant numbers of fighters for Al Qaeda and the Talib...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration is concerned that the approach of warmer weather in Afghanistan may signal a sharp rise in guerrilla attacks on American and allied troops, senior officials say. Significant numbers of fighters for Al Qaeda and the Taliban are thought to be regrouping in a mountainous stretch of eastern Afghanistan along the Pakistan border. As the peaks and high mountain passes thaw, those fighters will be able to move more freely in small groups -- making them harder to detect, track and attack, officials say. Other scattered cells of adversaries are believed to remain in the south and west.
docs.abstract: Bush administration officials fear approach of warmer weather in Afghanistan may signal sharp rise in guerrilla attacks on American and allied troops; suspect significant numbers of Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters are regrouping in mountains along Pakistan border and that other scattered cells of adversaries remain in south and west; note small clusters of fighters are hard to detect, track and attack (M)

headline.main: Guerrilla Attacks May Rise In Warmer Days, U.S. Says

docs.snippet: When the Colombian peace talks collapsed on Feb. 20, local authorities in towns and villages around the former peace zone had less than three hours' warning before President Andres Pastrana sent planes and helicopters to bomb their territory. They...
docs.lead_paragraph: When the Colombian peace talks collapsed on Feb. 20, local authorities in towns and villages around the former peace zone had less than three hours' warning before President Andres Pastrana sent planes and helicopters to bomb their territory. They had no time to organize protection for civilians. Georgina and Adam, who feared that divulging their full names would be unsafe, were two people I met in the village of Los Pozos. Their small plot abutted the government's negotiation site. None of the negotiators from the government or the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, known as FARC, ever dropped by to greet them. They are very poor, and the poor in Colombia are invisible.
docs.abstract: Ana Carrigan Op-Ed article urges United States not to take part in war between Colombian government and FARC guerrillas; holds guerrilla insurgency is symptom of national sickness deeply rooted in corrupt political system; holds government has preserved fiction of civilian, democratic rule by concealing its dominance by military that has blocked efforts to end war; calls on US to help strengthen independent democratic forces (M)

docs.snippet: THE insurance industry has long depended on fear of the unforeseen. Lately, the unforeseen has created a boom for a type of insurance coverage that has been around for years -- protection from political turmoil.    Events of the last six months --...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE insurance industry has long depended on fear of the unforeseen. Lately, the unforeseen has created a boom for a type of insurance coverage that has been around for years -- protection from political turmoil. Events of the last six months -- from the World Trade Center attacks and the United States war on terrorism to the economic crisis in Argentina -- have jolted multinational companies into remembering that the world is a dangerous place to do business.
docs.abstract: Insurance companies are doing brisk business in political risk coverage as American companies with overseas operations seek protection against against terrorism, riot, civil war, strikes, coups d'etat, nationalization and government interference with flow of profits back home; terrorism coverage used to be included in general property policies at little or no extra charge, but many property insurers are refusing to provide terrorism coverage that way, forcing companies to buy it separately or as part of political risk package; photo; table (M)

headline.main: Business; Insurers Find Profit in a New Risk Consciousness

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: COUPS D'ETAT AND ATTEMPTED COUPS D'ETAT

docs.snippet: John Walker, the 20-year-old Californian captured while fighting with the Taliban, learned of plans to send suicide teams to the United States three months before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, according to the criminal affidavit filed against hi...
docs.lead_paragraph: John Walker, the 20-year-old Californian captured while fighting with the Taliban, learned of plans to send suicide teams to the United States three months before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, according to the criminal affidavit filed against him. Mr. Walker learned of the plans while completing a seven-week course in a Qaeda training camp. There, he met at least once with Osama bin Laden, who ''thanked him for taking part in jihad,'' the affidavit said.
docs.abstract: Criminal complaint portrays John Walker as committed Taliban fighter familiar with Osama bin Laden's goals (M)

headline.main: Document Paints Portrait Of Committed Taliban Fighter

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    John C. Whitehead, chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, has suggested an international design competition for a Sept. 11 memorial (''Rebuilding Downtown,'' editorial, April 3). I was one of hundreds who entere...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: John C. Whitehead, chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, has suggested an international design competition for a Sept. 11 memorial (''Rebuilding Downtown,'' editorial, April 3). I was one of hundreds who entered the Vietnam Veterans Memorial design competition, and I remember -- and treasure -- the depth of emotion and effort that process brought forth. The brilliant design by Maya Lin that was selected ignored that part of the design program that cautioned against any negative comment on the conflict.
docs.abstract: John Mullen letter recalls emotion of submitting design for Vietnam Veterans Memorial; says events of Sept 11 deserve nothing less (S)

docs.snippet: If geology were destiny, Angola, with rich deposits of oil and diamonds and a relatively small population, would be one of Africa's most prosperous countries. Instead, more than a quarter-century of civil war and brazenly corrupt government have l...
docs.lead_paragraph: If geology were destiny, Angola, with rich deposits of oil and diamonds and a relatively small population, would be one of Africa's most prosperous countries. Instead, more than a quarter-century of civil war and brazenly corrupt government have left it a ruin. The death in combat last month of the longtime rebel leader Jonas Savimbi opens a possibility of finally ending the fighting, introducing more accountable government and using oil revenues to build a better life for Angola's people. For that to happen the ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, or M.P.L.A., will have to change its ways. Washington and the United Nations need to step up the pressure for reforms. So do international oil companies, whose payments keep Angola's government afloat. This year oil revenues of about $3 billion will account for about 90 percent of official government spending.
docs.abstract: Editorial says death of Jonas Savimbi, longtime rebel leader in Angola, opens possibility of finally ending more than quarter-century of civil war, but only if ruling Popular Movement for Liberation of Angola changes its ways; says US must press it to privatize state companies and introduce more financial transparency and democracy; says UN needs to resume efforts to negotiate peace agreement; says oil companies must insist on increased financial accountability and social investment as condition of developing new oilfields (M)
